body: Hi @ballcap231 . There is no concept of training time. Ludwig trains for certain amount of epochs and performs early stopping if a specific measure of performance on the validation set for a certain amount of epoch. In the [training section of the user guide](https://uber.github.io/ludwig/user_guide/#training) you can find all the parameters and you can change them to your liking.
This can turn in a feature request, but it is not a common pattern in machine learning, you usually specify either the number of epochs or the number of steps.
@w4nderlust definitely. But in AutoML, it is the most common way to regulate how to train (at least TPOT, H2O, AutoKeras and  AutoSklearn support it).
@manugarri can you provide some authoritative links about it? I'm considering it and want to be sure :)

Sure! 
- [autosklearn `time_left_for_this_task` example from the repo](https://github.com/automl/auto-sklearn/blob/master/examples/example_random_search.py#L74)
- [H2O `max_runtime_secs` docs ](http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/data-science/algo-params/max_runtime_secs.html) 
- [TPOT `max_time_mins` in the repo](https://github.com/EpistasisLab/tpot/blob/master/tpot/base.py#L113)
- [AutoKeras `time_limit` example from the repo](https://github.com/keras-team/autokeras/blob/master/examples/a_simple_example/mnist.py#L9)
Thank you so much. Will reopen this issue and transform it into a feature request.
@w4nderlust Do we have an update on this enhancement? It is vital for comparing Ludwig with other AutoML systems and as @manugarri mentioned, the common ground is `max_runtime`.

@iXanthos Ludwig is not an AutoML system, not sure where you got that from, certainly not from me :) Anyway, yes, this is a feature on our radar, but we have a few more with higher priority. This is not actually difficult to implement anyway, if you care about it I can give you precise directions on how to implement it and do a PR about it.

> @iXanthos Ludwig is not an AutoML system, not sure where you got that from, certainly not from me :) Anyway, yes, this is a feature on our radar, but we have a few more with higher priority. This is not actually difficult to implement anyway, if you care about it I can give you precise directions on how to implement it and do a PR about it.

AutoDL**. I would be interested, yeah.

@iXanthos it's not really about the ML/DL part, it's about the Auto part :) At the moment Ludwig has no way to specify directly an hyperparameter search, the only thing it does is providing you with reasonable default for your model configuration, there is nothing automatic other than the model composition, so I definitely wouldn't call it AutoML or AutoDL. At least not yet, as hyperopt is coming.

Regarding how to implement the timeout, it's pretty simple: you start a timer around line 427 of `models/model.py` at the beginning of the training, and then after each batch of training (line 580) you check if the timer is above the maximum time (you have to add an additional parameter for that in the train function signature), if that's true then you break, and you also want to add this check in the evaluation calls (608, 614, 623) and at the end of the epoch (741). Alternatively, you can create a scheduled timer that fires when passes the maximum time and calls a function that halts the training, similar to `set_epochs_to_1_or_quit`. Let me know if this is clear and if you need more details.
